column2: The Rusizi River--according to Ruhinga--rose near a lake called Kivo, which he said is as long as from Mugihawa to Mugere, and as broad as from Mugihewa to Warumashanya's country, or, say eighteen miles in length by about eight in breadth.
column3: The Rusizi River-according to Ruhinga-rose near a lake called Kivo, which he said is as long as from Mugihawa to Mugere, and as broad as from Mugihewa to Warumashanya's country, or, say eighteen miles in length by about eight in breadth.

column2: The lake is surrounded by mountains on the western and northern sides: on the south-western side of one of these mountains issues the Rusizi--at first a small rapid stream; but as it proceeds towards the lake it receives the rivers Kagunissi, Kaburan, Mohira, Nyamagana, Nyakagunda, Ruviro, Rofubu, Kavimvira, Myove, Ruhuha, Mukindu, Sange, Rubirizi, Kiriba, and, lastly, the Ruanda River, which seems to be the largest of them all.
column3: The lake is surrounded by mountains on the western and northern sides: on the south-western side of one of these mountains issues the Rusizi-at first a small rapid stream; but as it proceeds towards the lake it receives the rivers Kagunissi, Kaburan, Mohira, Nyamagana, Nyakagunda, Ruviro, Rofubu, Kavimvira, Myove, Ruhuha, Mukindu, Sange, Rubirizi, Kiriba, and, lastly, the Ruanda River, which seems to be the largest of them all.

column2: Kivo Lake is so called from the country in which it is situated.
column3: Kivo Lake is so called from the country in which it is situated.

column2: On one side is Mutumbi (probably the Utumbi of Speke and Baker), on the west is Ruanda; on the east is Urundi.
column3: On one side is Mutumbi (probably the Utumbi of Speke and Baker), on the west is Ruanda; on the east is Urundi.

column2: The name of the chief of Kivo is Kwansibura.
column3: The name of the chief of Kivo is Kwansibura.

column2: After so many minute details about the River Rusizi, it only remained for us to see it.
column3: After so many minute details about the River Rusizi, it only remained for us to see it.

column2: On the second morning of our arrival at Mugihewa we mustered ten strong paddlers, and set out to explore the head of the lake and the mouth of the Rusizi.
column3: On the second morning of our arrival at Mugihewa we mustered ten strong paddlers, and set out to explore the head of the lake and the mouth of the Rusizi.

column2: We found that the northern head of the lake was indented with seven broad bays, each from one and a half to three miles broad; that long broad spits of sand, overgrown with matete, separated each bay from the other.
column3: We found that the northern head of the lake was indented with seven broad bays, each from one and a half to three miles broad; that long broad spits of sand, overgrown with matete, separated each bay from the other.

column2: The first, starting from west to east, at the broadest part, to the extreme southern point of Mugihewa, was about three miles broad, and served as a line of demarcation between Mukamba's district of Ruwenga and Mugihewa of Ruhinga; it was also two miles deep.
column3: The first, starting from west to east, at the broadest part, to the extreme southern point of Mugihewa, was about three miles broad, and served as a line of demarcation between Mukamba's district of Ruwenga and Mugihewa of Ruhinga; it was also two miles deep.

column2: The second bay was a mile from the southern extremity of Mugihewa to Ruhinga's village at the head of the bay, and it was a mile across to another spit of sand which was terminated by a small island. The third bay stretched for nearly a mile to a long spit, at the end of which was another island, one and a quarter mile in length, and was the western side of the fourth bay, at the head of which was the delta of the Rusizi.
column3: The second bay was a mile from the southern extremity of Mugihewa to Ruhinga's village at the head of the bay, and it was a mile across to another spit of sand which was terminated by a small island. The third bay stretched for nearly a mile to a long spit, at the end of which was another island, one and a quarter mile in length, and was the western side of the fourth bay, at the head of which was the delta of the Rusizi.

column2: This fourth bay, at its base, was about three miles in depth, and penetrated half a mile further inland than any other. Soundings indicated six feet deep, and the same depth was kept to within a few hundred yards of the principal mouth of the Rusizi.
column3: This fourth bay, at its base, was about three miles in depth, and penetrated half a mile further inland than any other. Soundings indicated six feet deep, and the same depth was kept to within a few hundred yards of the principal mouth of the Rusizi.

column2: The current was very sluggish; not more than a mile an hour.
column3: The current was very sluggish; not more than a mile an hour.

column2: Though we constantly kept our binocular searching for the river, we could not see the main channel until within 200 yards of it, and then only by watching by what outlet the fishing; canoes came out.
column3: Though we constantly kept our binocular searching for the river, we could not see the main channel until within two hundred yards of it, and then only by watching by what outlet the fishing; canoes came out.

column2: The bay at this point had narrowed from two miles to about 200 yards in breadth.
column3: The bay at this point had narrowed from two miles to about two hundred yards in breadth.

column2: Inviting a canoe to show us the way, a small flotilla of canoes preceded us, from the sheer curiosity of their owners.
column3: Inviting a canoe to show us the way, a small flotilla of canoes preceded us, from the sheer curiosity of their owners.

column2: We followed, and in a few minutes were ascending the stream, which was very rapid, though but about ten yards wide, and very shallow; not more than two feet deep.
column3: We followed, and in a few minutes were ascending the stream, which was very rapid, though but about ten yards wide, and very shallow; not more than two feet deep.

column2: We ascended about half a mile, the current being very strong, from six to eight miles an hour, and quite far enough to observe the nature of the stream at its embouchure.
column3: We ascended about half a mile, the current being very strong, from six to eight miles an hour, and quite far enough to observe the nature of the stream at its embouchure.

column2: We could see that it widened and spread out in a myriad of channels, rushing by isolated clumps of sedge and matete grass; and that it had the appearance of a swamp.
column3: We could see that it widened and spread out in a myriad of channels, rushing by isolated clumps of sedge and matete grass; and that it had the appearance of a swamp.

column2: We had ascended the central, or main channel.
column3: We had ascended the central, or main channel.

column2: The western channel was about eight yards broad.
column3: The western channel was about eight yards broad.

column2: We observed, after we had returned to the bay, that the easternmost channel was about six yards broad, and about ten feet deep, but very sluggish.
column3: We observed, after we had returned to the bay, that the easternmost channel was about six yards broad, and about ten feet deep, but very sluggish.

column2: We had thus examined each of its three mouths, and settled all doubts as to the Rusizi being an effluent or influent.
column3: We had thus examined each of its three mouths, and settled all doubts as to the Rusizi being an effluent or influent.

column2: It was not necessary to ascend higher, there being nothing about the river itself to repay exploration of it.
column3: It was not necessary to ascend higher, there being nothing about the river itself to repay exploration of it.

column2: The question, "Was the Rusizi an effluent or an influent?" was answered for ever.
column3: The question, "Was the Rusizi an effluent or an influent?" was answered for ever.

column2: There was now no doubt any more on that point.
column3: There was now no doubt any more on that point.

column2: In size it was not to be compared with the Malagarazi River, neither is it, or can it be, navigable for anything but the smallest canoes.
column3: In size it was not to be compared with the Malagarazi River, neither is it, or can it be, navigable for anything but the smallest canoes.

column2: The only thing remarkable about it is that it abounds in crocodiles, but not one hippopotamus was seen; which may be taken as another evidence of its shallowness.
column3: The only thing remarkable about it is that it abounds in crocodiles, but not one hippopotamus was seen; which may be taken as another evidence of its shallowness.

column2: The bays to the east of the Rusizi are of the same conformation as those on the west.
column3: The bays to the east of the Rusizi are of the same conformation as those on the west.

column2: Carefully judging from the width of the several bays from point to point, and of the several spits which separate them, the breadth of the lake may be said to be about twelve or fourteen miles.
column3: Carefully judging from the width of the several bays from point to point, and of the several spits which separate them, the breadth of the lake may be said to be about twelve or fourteen miles.

column2: Had we contented ourselves with simply looking at the conformation, and the meeting of the eastern and western ranges, we should have said that the lake ended in a point, as Captain Speke has sketched it on his map.
column3: Had we contented ourselves with simply looking at the conformation, and the meeting of the eastern and western ranges, we should have said that the lake ended in a point, as Captain Speke has sketched it on his map.

column2: But its exploration dissolved that idea.
column3: But its exploration dissolved that idea.

column2: Chamati Hill is the extreme northern termination of the western range, and seems, upon a superficial examination, to abut against the Ramata mountains of the eastern range, which are opposite Chamati; but a valley about a mile in breadth separates the two ranges, and through this valley the Rusizi flows towards the lake.* Though Chamati terminates the western range, the eastern range continues for miles beyond, north-westerly.
column3: Chamati Hill is the extreme northern termination of the western range, and seems, upon a superficial examination, to abut against the Ramata mountains of the eastern range, which are opposite Chamati; but a valley about a mile in breadth separates the two ranges, and through this valley the Rusizi flows towards the lake.asterisk Though Chamati terminates the western range, the eastern range continues for miles beyond, north westerly.

column2: After its issue from this broad gorge, the Rusizi runs seemingly in a broad and mighty stream, through a wide alluvial plain, its own formation, in a hundred channels, until, approaching the lake, it flows into it by three channels only, as above described. ______________ * After the patient investigation of the North end of the Lake, and satisfying ourselves by personal observation that the Rusizi ran into the Lake, the native rumor which Sir Samuel Baker brought home that the Tanganika and the Albert N'Yanza have a water connection still finds many believers!
column3: After its issue from this broad gorge, the Rusizi runs seemingly in a broad and mighty stream, through a wide alluvial plain, its own formation, in a hundred channels, until, approaching the lake, it flows into it by three channels only, as above described. , blank , asterisk After the patient investigation of the North end of the Lake, and satisfying ourselves by personal observation that the Rusizi ran into the Lake, the native rumor which Sir Samuel Baker brought home that the Tanganika and the Albert N'Yanza have a water connection still finds many believers!
, blank ,

column2: I should not omit to state here, that though the Doctor and I have had to contend against the strong current of the Rusizi River, as it flowed swift and strong INTO the Tanganika, the Doctor still adheres to the conviction that, whatever part the Rusizi plays, there must be an outlet to the Tanganika somewhere, from the fact that all fresh-water lakes have outlets, The Doctor is able to state his opinions and reasons far better than I can find for him; and, lest I misconstrue the subject, I shall leave it until he has an opportunity to explain them himself; which his great knowledge of Africa will enable him to do with advantage.
column3: I should not omit to state here, that though the Doctor and I have had to contend against the strong current of the Rusizi River, as it flowed swift and strong INTO the Tanganika, the Doctor still adheres to the conviction that, whatever part the Rusizi plays, there must be an outlet to the Tanganika somewhere, from the fact that all fresh water lakes have outlets, The Doctor is able to state his opinions and reasons far better than I can find for him; and, lest I misconstrue the subject, I shall leave it until he has an opportunity to explain them himself; which his great knowledge of Africa will enable him to do with advantage.

column2: One thing is evident to me, and I believe to the Doctor, that Sir Samuel Baker will have to curtail the Albert N'Yanza by one, if not two degrees of latitude.
column3: One thing is evident to me, and I believe to the Doctor, that Sir Samuel Baker will have to curtail the Albert N'Yanza by one, if not two degrees of latitude.

column2: That well-known traveller has drawn his lake far into the territory of the Warundi, while Ruanda has been placed on the eastern side; whereas a large portion of it, if not all, should be placed north of what he has designated on his map as Usige.
column3: That well-known traveller has drawn his lake far into the territory of the Warundi, while Ruanda has been placed on the eastern side; whereas a large portion of it, if not all, should be placed north of what he has designated on his map as Usige.

column2: The information of such an intelligent man as Ruhinga is not to be despised; for, if Lake Albert came within a hundred miles of the Tanganika, he would surely have heard of its existence, even if he had not seen it himself.
column3: The information of such an intelligent man as Ruhinga is not to be despised; for, if Lake Albert came within a hundred miles of the Tanganika, he would surely have heard of its existence, even if he had not seen it himself.

column2: Originally he came from Mutumbi, and he has travelled from that country into Mugihewa, the district he now governs.
column3: Originally he came from Mutumbi, and he has travelled from that country into Mugihewa, the district he now governs.

column2: He has seen Mwezi, the great King of Urundi, and describes him as a man about forty years old, and as a very good man.
column3: He has seen Mwezi, the great King of Urundi, and describes him as a man about forty years old, and as a very good man.

column2: Our work was now done; there was nothing more to detain us at Mugihewa. Ruhinga had been exceedingly kind, and given us one ox after another to butcher and eat.
column3: Our work was now done; there was nothing more to detain us at Mugihewa. Ruhinga had been exceedingly kind, and given us one ox after another to butcher and eat.

column2: Mukamba had done the same.
column3: Mukamba had done the same.

column2: Their women had supplied us with an abundance of milk and butter, and we had now bounteous supplies of both.
column3: Their women had supplied us with an abundance of milk and butter, and we had now bounteous supplies of both.

column2: The Doctor had taken a series of observations for latitude and longitude; and Mugihewa was made out to be in 3 degrees 19 minutes S. latitude.
column3: The Doctor had taken a series of observations for latitude and longitude; and Mugihewa was made out to be in three degrees nineteen minutes s latitude.

column2: On the 7th December, early in the morning, we left Mugihewa, and rowing past the southern extremity of the Katangara Islands, we approached the highlands of Uashi near the boundary line between Mukamba's country and Uvira.
column3: On the seventh of december, early in the morning, we left Mugihewa, and rowing past the southern extremity of the Katangara Islands, we approached the highlands of Uashi near the boundary line between Mukamba's country and Uvira.

column2: The boundary line is supposed to be a wide ravine, in the depths of which is a grove of tall, beautiful, and straight-stemmed trees, out of which the natives make their canoes.
column3: The boundary line is supposed to be a wide ravine, in the depths of which is a grove of tall, beautiful, and straight stemmed trees, out of which the natives make their canoes.

column2: Passing Kanyamabengu River, which issues into the lake close to the market-ground of Kirabula, the extreme point of Burton and Speke's explorations of the Tanganika, we steered south along the western shore of the lake for half an hour longer to Kavimba, where we halted to cook breakfast.
column3: Passing Kanyamabengu River, which issues into the lake close to the market ground of Kirabula, the extreme point of Burton and Speke's explorations of the Tanganika, we steered south along the western shore of the lake for half an hour longer to Kavimba, where we halted to cook breakfast.

column2: The village where lived Mruta, the King of Uvira, was in sight of our encampment, and as we observed parties of men ascending and descending the mountains much more often than we thought augured good to ourselves, we determined to continue on our course south.
column3: The village where lived m ruta, the King of Uvira, was in sight of our encampment, and as we observed parties of men ascending and descending the mountains much more often than we thought augured good to ourselves, we determined to continue on our course south.

column2: Besides, there was a party of disconsolate-looking Wajiji here, who had been plundered only a few days before our arrival, for attempting, as the Wavira believed, to evade the honga payment.
column3: Besides, there was a party of disconsolate looking Wajiji here, who had been plundered only a few days before our arrival, for attempting, as the Wavira believed, to evade the honga payment.

column2: Such facts as these, and our knowledge of the general state of insecurity in the country, resulting from the many wars in which the districts of the Tanganika were engaged, determined us not to halt at Kavimba.
column3: Such facts as these, and our knowledge of the general state of insecurity in the country, resulting from the many wars in which the districts of the Tanganika were engaged, determined us not to halt at Kavimba.

column2: We embarked quickly in our boat before the Wavira had collected themselves, and headed south against a strong gale, which came driving down on us from the south-west.
column3: We embarked quickly in our boat before the Wavira had collected themselves, and headed south against a strong gale, which came driving down on us from the south-west.

column2: After a hard pull of about two hours in the teeth of the storm, which was rapidly rising, we pointed the head of the boat into a little quiet cove, almost hidden in tall reeds, and disembarked for the night.
column3: After a hard pull of about two hours in the teeth of the storm, which was rapidly rising, we pointed the head of the boat into a little quiet cove, almost hidden in tall reeds, and disembarked for the night.

column2: Cognizant of the dangers which surrounded us, knowing, that savage and implacable man was the worst enemy we had to fear, we employed our utmost energies in the construction of a stout fence of thorn bushes, and then sat down to supper after our work was done, and turned in to sleep; but not before we had posted watchmen to guard our canoe, lest the daring thieves of Uvira might abstract it, in which case we should have been in a pretty plight, and in most unenviable distress.
column3: Cognizant of the dangers which surrounded us, knowing, that savage and implacable man was the worst enemy we had to fear, we employed our utmost energies in the construction of a stout fence of thorn bushes, and then sat down to supper after our work was done, and turned in to sleep; but not before we had posted watchmen to guard our canoe, lest the daring thieves of Uvira might abstract it, in which case we should have been in a pretty plight, and in most unenviable distress.

column2: At daybreak, leaving Kukumba Point after our humble breakfast of coffee, cheese, and dourra cakes was despatched, we steered south once more. Our fires had attracted the notice of the sharp-eyed and suspicious fishermen of Kukumba; but our precautions and the vigilant watch we had set before retiring, had proved an effectual safeguard against the Kivira thieves.
column3: At daybreak, leaving Kukumba Point after our humble breakfast of coffee, cheese, and dourra cakes was despatched, we steered south once more. Our fires had attracted the notice of the sharp eyed and suspicious fishermen of Kukumba; but our precautions and the vigilant watch we had set before retiring, had proved an effectual safeguard against the Kivira thieves.

column2: The western shores of the lake as we proceeded were loftier, and more bold than the wooded heights of Urundi and bearded knolls of Ujiji.
column3: The western shores of the lake as we proceeded were loftier, and more bold than the wooded heights of Urundi and bearded knolls of Ujiji.

column2: A back ridge--the vanguard of the mountains which rise beyond--disclosed itself between the serrated tops of the front line of mountains, which rose to a height of from 2,500 to 3,000 feet above the lake.
column3: A back ridge-the vanguard of the mountains which rise beyond-disclosed itself between the serrated tops of the front line of mountains, which rose to a height of from two thousand five hundred to three thousand feet above the lake.

column2: Within the folds of the front line of mountains rise isolated hills of considerable magnitude, precipitous and abrupt, but scenically very picturesque. The greater part of these hills have the rounded and smooth top, or are tabularly summited.
column3: Within the folds of the front line of mountains rise isolated hills of considerable magnitude, precipitous and abrupt, but scenically very picturesque. The greater part of these hills have the rounded and smooth top, or are tabularly summited.

column2: The ridge enfolding these hills shoots out, at intervals, promontorial projections of gradual sloping outlines, which on the map I have designated capes, or points.
column3: The ridge enfolding these hills shoots out, at intervals, promontorial projections of gradual sloping outlines, which on the map I have designated capes, or points.

column2: When rounding these points, up went our compasses for the taking of bearings, and observing the directions of all prominent objects of interest.
column3: When rounding these points, up went our compasses for the taking of bearings, and observing the directions of all prominent objects of interest.

column2: Often these capes are formed by the alluvial plains, through which we may be sure a river will be found flowing.
column3: Often these capes are formed by the alluvial plains, through which we may be sure a river will be found flowing.

column2: These pretty alluvial plains, enfolded on the south, the west, and the north by a grand mountain arc, present most luxurious and enchanting scenery.
column3: These pretty alluvial plains, enfolded on the south, the west, and the north by a grand mountain arc, present most luxurious and enchanting scenery.

column2: The vegetation seems to be of spontaneous growth.
column3: The vegetation seems to be of spontaneous growth.

column2: Groups of the Elaeis Guineansis palm embowering some dun-brown village; an array of majestic, superb growth of mvule trees; a broad extent covered with vivid green sorghum stalks; parachute-like tops of mimosa; a line of white sand, on which native canoes are drawn far above the reach of the plangent, uneasy surf; fishermen idly reclining in the shade of a tree;--these are the scenes which reveal themselves to us as we voyage in our canoe on the Tanganika.
column3: Groups of the Elaeis Guineansis palm embowering some dun brown village; an array of majestic, superb growth of m vule trees; a broad extent covered with vivid green sorghum stalks; parachute like tops of mimosa; a line of white sand, on which native canoes are drawn far above the reach of the plangent, uneasy surf; fishermen idly reclining in the shade of a tree;--these are the scenes which reveal themselves to us as we voyage in our canoe on the Tanganika.

column2: When wearied with the romance of wild tropic scenes such as these, we have but to lift our eyes to the great mountain tops looming darkly and grandly on our right; to watch the light pencilling of the cirrus, brushing their summits, as it is drifted toward the north by the rising wind: to watch the changing forms which the clouds assume, from the fleecy horizontal bars of the cirrus, to the denser, gloomier cumulus, prognosticator of storm and rain, which soon settles into a portentous group--Alps above Alps, one above another--and we know the storm which was brewing is at hand, and that it is time to seek shelter.
column3: When wearied with the romance of wild tropic scenes such as these, we have but to lift our eyes to the great mountain tops looming darkly and grandly on our right; to watch the light pencilling of the cirrus, brushing their summits, as it is drifted toward the north by the rising wind: to watch the changing forms which the clouds assume, from the fleecy horizontal bars of the cirrus, to the denser, gloomier cumulus, prognosticator of storm and rain, which soon settles into a portentous group-Alps above Alps, one above another-and we know the storm which was brewing is at hand, and that it is time to seek shelter.

column2: Passing Muikamba, we saw several groves of the tall mvule tree.
column3: Passing Muikamba, we saw several groves of the tall m vule tree.

column2: As far as Bemba the Wabembe occupy the mountain summits, while the Wavira cultivate the alluvial plains along the base and lower slopes of the mountain.
column3: As far as Bemba the Wabembe occupy the mountain summits, while the Wavira cultivate the alluvial plains along the base and lower slopes of the mountain.

column2: At Bemba we halted to take in pieces of pipe-clay, in accordance with the superstition of the Wajiji, who thought us certain of safe passage and good fortune if we complied with the ancient custom.
column3: At Bemba we halted to take in pieces of pipe clay, in accordance with the superstition of the Wajiji, who thought us certain of safe passage and good fortune if we complied with the ancient custom.

column2: Passing Ngovi, we came to a deep bend, which curved off to Cape Kabogi at the distance of ten miles.
column3: Passing Ngovi, we came to a deep bend, which curved off to Cape Kabogi at the distance of ten miles.

column2: About two-thirds of the way we arrived at a group of islets, three in number, all very steep and rocky; the largest about 300 feet in length at the base, and about 200 feet in breadth.
column3: About two thirds of the way we arrived at a group of islets, three in number, all very steep and rocky; the largest about three hundred feet in length at the base, and about two hundred feet in breadth.

column2: Here we made preparations to halt for the night.
column3: Here we made preparations to halt for the night.

column2: The inhabitants of the island were a gorgeously-feathered old cock, which was kept as a propitiatory offering to the spirit of the island, a sickly yellow-looking thrush, a hammer-headed stork, and two fish-hawks, who, finding we had taken possession of what had been religiously reserved for them, took flight to the most western island, where from their perches they continued to eye us most solemnly.
column3: The inhabitants of the island were a gorgeously feathered old cock, which was kept as a propitiatory offering to the spirit of the island, a sickly yellow looking thrush, a hammer headed stork, and two fish hawks, who, finding we had taken possession of what had been religiously reserved for them, took flight to the most western island, where from their perches they continued to eye us most solemnly.

column2: As these islands were with difficulty pronounced by us as Kavunvweh, the Doctor, seeing that they were the only objects we were likely to discover, named them the "'New York Herald' Islets;" and, in confirmation of the new designation given them, shook hands with me upon it.
column3: As these islands were with difficulty pronounced by us as Kavunvweh, the Doctor, seeing that they were the only objects we were likely to discover, named them the "'New York Herald' Islets;" and, in confirmation of the new designation given them, shook hands with me upon it.

column2: Careful dead-reckoning settled them to be in lat.
column3: Careful dead reckoning settled them to be in lat.

column2: 3 degrees 41 minutes S.
column3: three degrees forty one minutes s

column2: The summit of the largest island was well adapted to take bearings, and we improved the opportunity, as most extensive views of the broad and lengthy lake and surrounding lines of imposing mountains were attainable.
column3: The summit of the largest island was well adapted to take bearings, and we improved the opportunity, as most extensive views of the broad and lengthy lake and surrounding lines of imposing mountains were attainable.

column2: The Ramata Hills were clearly visible, and bore N.N.E. from it; Katanga Cape, S.E. by S.; Sentakeyi, E.S.E.; Magala, E. by N.; south-western point of Muzimu bore S., northern point of Muzimu island, S.S.E.
column3: The Ramata Hills were clearly visible, and bore n n e from it; Katanga Cape, s e by s; Sentakeyi, e s e; Magala, e by n; south-western point of Muzimu bore s, northern point of Muzimu island, s s e

column2: At dawn on the 9th December we prepared to resume our voyage.
column3: At dawn on the ninth of december we prepared to resume our voyage.

column2: Once or twice in the night we had been visited by fishermen, but our anxious watchfulness prevented any marauding.
column3: Once or twice in the night we had been visited by fishermen, but our anxious watchfulness prevented any marauding.

column2: It seemed to me, however, that the people of the opposite shore, who were our visitors, were eagerly watching an opportunity to pounce upon our canoe, or take us bodily for a prey; and our men were considerably affected by these thoughts, if we may judge from the hearty good-will with which they rowed away from our late encampment.
column3: It seemed to me, however, that the people of the opposite shore, who were our visitors, were eagerly watching an opportunity to pounce upon our canoe, or take us bodily for a prey; and our men were considerably affected by these thoughts, if we may judge from the hearty good will with which they rowed away from our late encampment.

column2: Arriving at Cape Kabogi, we came to the territory of the Wasansi.
column3: Arriving at Cape Kabogi, we came to the territory of the Wasansi.

column2: We knew we were abreast of a different tribe by the greeting "Moholo," which a group of fishermen gave us; as that of the Wavira was "Wake," like that of Urundi, Usige, and Uhha.
column3: We knew we were abreast of a different tribe by the greeting "Moholo," which a group of fishermen gave us; as that of the Wavira was "Wake," like that of Urundi, Usige, and u h h a.

column2: We soon sighted Cape Luvumba--a sloping projection of a mountain ridge which shot far into the lake.
column3: We soon sighted Cape Luvumba-a sloping projection of a mountain ridge which shot far into the lake.

column2: As a storm was brewing, we steered for a snug little cove that appeared before a village; and, drawing our canoe from the water, began to set the tent, and make other preparations for passing the night.
column3: As a storm was brewing, we steered for a snug little cove that appeared before a village; and, drawing our canoe from the water, began to set the tent, and make other preparations for passing the night.

column2: As the natives appeared quiet and civil enough, we saw no reason to suspect that they entertained any hostility to Arabs and Wangwana. Accordingly we had our breakfast cooked, and as usual laid down for an afternoon nap.
column3: As the natives appeared quiet and civil enough, we saw no reason to suspect that they entertained any hostility to Arabs and Wangwana. Accordingly we had our breakfast cooked, and as usual laid down for an afternoon nap.

column2: I soon fell asleep, and was dreaming away in my tent, in happy oblivion of the strife and contention that had risen since I had gone to sleep, when I heard a voice hailing me with, "Master, master! get up, quick.
column3: I soon fell asleep, and was dreaming away in my tent, in happy oblivion of the strife and contention that had risen since I had gone to sleep, when I heard a voice hailing me with, "Master, master! get up, quick.

column2: Here is a fight going to begin!" I sprang up, and snatching my revolver belt from the gun-stand, walked outside.
column3: Here is a fight going to begin!" I sprang up, and snatching my revolver belt from the gun stand, walked outside.

column2: Surely, there appeared to be considerable animus between the several factions; between a noisy, vindictive-looking set of natives of the one part, and our people of the other part.
column3: Surely, there appeared to be considerable animus between the several factions; between a noisy, vindictive looking set of natives of the one part, and our people of the other part.

column2: Seven or eight of our people had taken refuge behind the canoe, and had their loaded guns half pointing at the passionate mob, which was momentarily increasing in numbers, but I could not see the Doctor anywhere.
column3: Seven or eight of our people had taken refuge behind the canoe, and had their loaded guns half pointing at the passionate mob, which was momentarily increasing in numbers, but I could not see the Doctor anywhere.

column2: Where is the Doctor? I asked.
column3: Where is the Doctor? I asked.

column2: He has gone over that hill, sir, with his compass, said Selim.
column3: He has gone over that hill, sir, with his compass, said Selim.

column2: Anybody with him?
column3: Anybody with him?

column2: Susi and Chumah.
column3: Susi and Chumah.

column2: You, Bombay, send two men off to warn the Doctor, and tell him to hurry up here.
column3: You, Bombay, send two men off to warn the Doctor, and tell him to hurry up here.

column2: But just at this period the Doctor and his two men appeared on the brow of the hill, looking down in a most complacent manner upon the serio-comic scene that the little basin wherein we were encamped presented.
column3: But just at this period the Doctor and his two men appeared on the brow of the hill, looking down in a most complacent manner upon the serio comic scene that the little basin wherein we were encamped presented.

column2: For, indeed, despite the serious aspect of it, there was much that was comical blended with it--in a naked young man who--perfectly drunk, barely able to stand on his feet--was beating the ground with his only loin-cloth, screaming and storming away like a madman; declaring by this, and by that, in his own choice language, that no Mgwana or Arab should halt one moment on the sacred soil of Usansi.
column3: For, indeed, despite the serious aspect of it, there was much that was comical blended with it-in a naked young man who-perfectly drunk, barely able to stand on his feet-was beating the ground with his only loin cloth, screaming and storming away like a madman; declaring by this, and by that, in his own choice language, that no m g wana or Arab should halt one moment on the sacred soil of Usansi.

column2: His father, the Sultan, was as inebriated as himself, though not quite so violent in his behaviour.
column3: His father, the Sultan, was as inebriated as himself, though not quite so violent in his behaviour.

column2: In the meantime the Doctor arrived upon the scene, and Selim had slipped my Winchester rifle, with the magazine full of cartridges, into my hand.
column3: In the meantime the Doctor arrived upon the scene, and Selim had slipped my Winchester rifle, with the magazine full of cartridges, into my hand.

column2: The Doctor calmly asked what was the matter, and was answered by the Wajiji guides that the people wished us to leave, as they were on hostile terms with the Arabs, because the eldest son of the Sultan of Muzimu, the large island nearly opposite, had been beaten to death by a Baluch, named Khamis, at Ujiji, because the young fellow had dared look into his harem, and ever since peace had been broken between the Wasansi and Arabs.
column3: The Doctor calmly asked what was the matter, and was answered by the Wajiji guides that the people wished us to leave, as they were on hostile terms with the Arabs, because the eldest son of the Sultan of Muzimu, the large island nearly opposite, had been beaten to death by a Baluch, named Khamis, at Ujiji, because the young fellow had dared look into his harem, and ever since peace had been broken between the Wasansi and Arabs.

column2: After consulting with the guides, the Doctor and I came to the conclusion that it were better that we should endeavour to pacify the Sultan by a present, rather than take offence at a drunken boy's extravagant freak.
column3: After consulting with the guides, the Doctor and I came to the conclusion that it were better that we should endeavour to pacify the Sultan by a present, rather than take offence at a drunken boy's extravagant freak.

column2: In his insane fury he had attempted to slash at one of my men with a billhook he carried.
column3: In his insane fury he had attempted to slash at one of my men with a billhook he carried.

column2: This had been taken as a declaration of hostilities, and the soldiers were ready enough to engage in war; but there was no necessity to commence fighting with a drunken mob, who could have been cleared off the ground with our revolvers alone had we desired it.
column3: This had been taken as a declaration of hostilities, and the soldiers were ready enough to engage in war; but there was no necessity to commence fighting with a drunken mob, who could have been cleared off the ground with our revolvers alone had we desired it.

column2: The Doctor, baring his arm, said to them that he was not a Mgwana, or an Arab; but a white man; that Arabs and Wangwana had no such colour as we had.
column3: The Doctor, baring his arm, said to them that he was not a m g wana, or an Arab; but a white man; that Arabs and Wangwana had no such colour as we had.

column2: We were white men, different people altogether from those whom they were accustomed to see: that no black men had ever suffered injury from white men.
column3: We were white men, different people altogether from those whom they were accustomed to see: that no black men had ever suffered injury from white men.

column2: This seemed to produce great effect, for after a little gentle persuasion the drunken youth, and his no less inebriate sire, were induced to sit down to talk quietly.
column3: This seemed to produce great effect, for after a little gentle persuasion the drunken youth, and his no less inebriate sire, were induced to sit down to talk quietly.

column2: In their conversation with us, they frequently referred to Mombo, the son of Kisesa, Sultan of Muzimu, who was brutally murdered.
column3: In their conversation with us, they frequently referred to Mombo, the son of Kisesa, Sultan of Muzimu, who was brutally murdered.

column2: Yes, brutally murdered! they exclaimed several times, in their own tongue; illustrating, by a faithful pantomime, how the unfortunate youth had died.
column3: Yes, brutally murdered! they exclaimed several times, in their own tongue; illustrating, by a faithful pantomime, how the unfortunate youth had died.

column2: Livingstone continued talking with them in a mild, paternal way, and their loud protestations against Arab cruelty were about to subside, when the old Sultan suddenly rose up and began to pace about in an excited manner, and in one of his perambulations deliberately slashed his leg with the sharp blade of his spear, and then exclaimed that the Wangwana had wounded him!
column3: Livingstone continued talking with them in a mild, paternal way, and their loud protestations against Arab cruelty were about to subside, when the old Sultan suddenly rose up and began to pace about in an excited manner, and in one of his perambulations deliberately slashed his leg with the sharp blade of his spear, and then exclaimed that the Wangwana had wounded him!

column2: At this cry one half of the mob hastily took to flight, but one old woman, who carried a strong staff with a carved lizard's body on its top, commenced to abuse the chief with all the power of her voluble tongue, charging him with a desire to have them all killed, and other women joined in with her in advising him to be quiet, and accept the present we were willing to give.
column3: At this cry one half of the mob hastily took to flight, but one old woman, who carried a strong staff with a carved lizard's body on its top, commenced to abuse the chief with all the power of her voluble tongue, charging him with a desire to have them all killed, and other women joined in with her in advising him to be quiet, and accept the present we were willing to give.

column2: But it is evident that there was little needed to cause all men present in that little hollow to begin a most sanguinary strife.
column3: But it is evident that there was little needed to cause all men present in that little hollow to begin a most sanguinary strife.

column2: The gentle, patient bearing of the Doctor had more effect than anything else in making all forbear bloodshed, while there was left the least chance of an amicable settlement, and in the end it prevailed.
column3: The gentle, patient bearing of the Doctor had more effect than anything else in making all forbear bloodshed, while there was left the least chance of an amicable settlement, and in the end it prevailed.

column2: The Sultan and his son were both sent on their way rejoicing.
column3: The Sultan and his son were both sent on their way rejoicing.

column2: While the Doctor conversed with them, and endeavoured to calm their fierce passions, I had the tent struck, and the canoes launched, and the baggage stowed, and when the negotiations had concluded amicably, I begged the Doctor to jump into the boat, as this apparent peace was simply a lull before a storm; besides, said I, there are two or three cowardly creatures in the boat, who, in case of another disturbance, would not scruple to leave both of us here.
column3: While the Doctor conversed with them, and endeavoured to calm their fierce passions, I had the tent struck, and the canoes launched, and the baggage stowed, and when the negotiations had concluded amicably, I begged the Doctor to jump into the boat, as this apparent peace was simply a lull before a storm; besides, said I, there are two or three cowardly creatures in the boat, who, in case of another disturbance, would not scruple to leave both of us here.

column2: From Cape Luvumba, about 4.30 P.M. we commenced pulling across; at 8 P.M. we were abreast of Cape Panza, the northern extremity of the island of Muzimu; at 6 A.M. we were southward of Bikari, and pulling for Mukungu, in Urundi, at which place we arrived at 10 A.M., having been seventeen hours and a half in crossing the lake, which, computing at two miles an hour, may be said to be thirty-five miles direct breadth, and a little more than forty-three miles from Cape Luvumba.
column3: From Cape Luvumba, about four thirty p m we commenced pulling across; at eight p m we were abreast of Cape Panza, the northern extremity of the island of Muzimu; at six a m we were southward of Bikari, and pulling for Mukungu, in Urundi, at which place we arrived at ten a m, having been seventeen hours and a half in crossing the lake, which, computing at two miles an hour, may be said to be thirty five miles direct breadth, and a little more than forty three miles from Cape Luvumba.

column2: On the 11th of December, after seven hours' pulling, we arrived at picturesque Zassi again; on the 12th, at the pretty cove of Niasanga; and at 11 A.M. we had rounded past Bangwe, and Ujiji was before us.
column3: On the eleventh of December, after seven hours' pulling, we arrived at picturesque Zassi again; on the twelfth, at the pretty cove of Niasanga; and at eleven a m we had rounded past Bangwe, and Ujiji was before us.

column2: We entered the port very quietly, without the usual firing of guns, as we were short of powder and ball.
column3: We entered the port very quietly, without the usual firing of guns, as we were short of powder and ball.

column2: As we landed, our soldiers and the Arab magnates came to the water's edge to greet us.
column3: As we landed, our soldiers and the Arab magnates came to the water's edge to greet us.

column2: Mabruki had a rich budget to relate to us, of what had occurred during our absence.
column3: Mabruki had a rich budget to relate to us, of what had occurred during our absence.

column2: This faithful man, left behind in charge of Livingstone's house, had done most excellently.
column3: This faithful man, left behind in charge of Livingstone's house, had done most excellently.

column2: Kalulu had scalded himself, and had a frightful raw sore on his chest in consequence.
column3: Kalulu had scalded himself, and had a frightful raw sore on his chest in consequence.

column2: Mabruki had locked up Marora in chains for wounding one of the asses.
column3: Mabruki had locked up Marora in chains for wounding one of the asses.

column2: Bilali, the stuttering coward, a bully of women, had caused a tumult in the market-place, and had been sharply belaboured with the stick by Mabruki.
column3: Bilali, the stuttering coward, a bully of women, had caused a tumult in the market place, and had been sharply belaboured with the stick by Mabruki.

column2: And, above all most welcome, was a letter I received from the American Consul at Zanzibar, dated June 11th, containing telegrams from Paris as late as April 22nd of the same year!
column3: And, above all most welcome, was a letter I received from the American Consul at Zanzibar, dated june eleventh, containing telegrams from Paris as late as april twenty second of the same year!

column2: Poor Livingstone exclaimed, "And I have none.
column3: Poor Livingstone exclaimed, "And I have none.

column2: What a pleasant thing it is to have a real and good friend!"
column3: What a pleasant thing it is to have a real and good friend!"

column2: Our voyage on the Tanganika had lasted twenty-eight days, during which time we had traversed over 300 miles of water.
column3: Our voyage on the Tanganika had lasted twenty eight days, during which time we had traversed over three hundred miles of water.

column2: CHAPTER XIV.
column3: CHAPTER fourteen.

column2: -- OUR JOURNEY FROM UJIJI TO UNYANYEMBE.
column3: -- OUR JOURNEY FROM u j i j i TO u n y a n y e m b e.

column2: We felt quite at home when we sat down on our black bear-skin, gay Persian carpet and clean new mats, to rest with our backs to the wall, sipping our tea with the air of comfortable men, and chat over the incidents of the "picnic," as Livingstone persisted in calling our journey to the Rusizi.
column3: We felt quite at home when we sat down on our black bear skin, gay Persian carpet and clean new mats, to rest with our backs to the wall, sipping our tea with the air of comfortable men, and chat over the incidents of the "picnic," as Livingstone persisted in calling our journey to the Rusizi.

column2: It seemed as if old times, which we loved to recall, had come back again, though our house was humble enough in its aspect, and our servants were only naked barbarians; but it was near this house that I had met him--Livingstone--after that eventful march from Unyanyembe; it was on this same veranda that I listened to that wonderful story of his about those far, enchanting regions west of the Lake Tanganika; it was in this same spot that I first became acquainted with him; and ever since my admiration has been growing for him, and I feel elated when he informs me that he must go to Unyanyembe under my escort, and at my expense.
column3: It seemed as if old times, which we loved to recall, had come back again, though our house was humble enough in its aspect, and our servants were only naked barbarians; but it was near this house that I had met him-Livingstone-after that eventful march from Unyanyembe; it was on this same veranda that I listened to that wonderful story of his about those far, enchanting regions west of the Lake Tanganika; it was in this same spot that I first became acquainted with him; and ever since my admiration has been growing for him, and I feel elated when he informs me that he must go to Unyanyembe under my escort, and at my expense.

column2: The old mud walls and the bare rafters, and the ancient thatched roof, and this queer-looking old veranda, will have an historical interest for me while I live, and so, while I can, I have taken pains and immortalized the humble old building by a sketch.
column3: The old mud walls and the bare rafters, and the ancient thatched roof, and this queer looking old veranda, will have an historical interest for me while I live, and so, while I can, I have taken pains and immortalized the humble old building by a sketch.
